title: Variables
summary: Variables store values so you can reuse them later. They have names and can hold different types of values (like numbers, text, or booleans). You assign a value to a variable and then refer to that name to use the value elsewhere in your code.
sample_question: What is a variable and why is it useful?

title: Loops
summary: Loops let you repeat an action multiple times. A 'for' loop typically repeats a known number of times (iterating over a range or collection), while a 'while' loop repeats as long as a condition remains true.
sample_question: Explain the difference between a for loop and a while loop.

title: Functions
summary: Functions bundle a set of instructions into a named block you can call multiple times. They help organize code, avoid repetition, and make programs easier to read and test.
sample_question: What is a function and when should you create one?

title: Conditionals
summary: Conditionals allow your program to make decisions. Using 'if', 'else if', and 'else', you can run different blocks of code depending on whether certain conditions are true.
sample_question: How do if-else statements help in decision-making in code?

title: Arrays / Lists
summary: Arrays (or lists) store multiple values in a single variable. They keep items in order and let you access each value using an index. Useful when working with collections of data.
sample_question: What is an array and when would you use one?

title: Objects
summary: Objects store data in key-value pairs and can also contain functions. They are used to model real-world things (like a user, product, or car) by grouping related data together.
sample_question: How do objects help you structure data in your program?

title: Classes
summary: Classes define blueprints for creating objects. They help you write organized, reusable code following the principles of Object-Oriented Programming (OOP).
sample_question: What is a class and how is it used in OOP?

title: Asynchronous Programming
summary: Asynchronous programming allows code to run without blocking other operations. It uses concepts like callbacks, promises, and async/await to handle tasks such as API calls or file loading.
sample_question: Why is asynchronous programming important, and what problems does it solve?

title: Error Handling
summary: Error handling helps your program react properly when something goes wrong. Techniques include try/catch blocks, custom error messages, and fallback behavior.
sample_question: How does try-catch improve the reliability of a program?

title: Data Structures
summary: Data structures organize data efficiently so it can be accessed, modified, and stored effectively. Common ones include arrays, stacks, queues, trees, and hash maps.
sample_question: What is a data structure and why are different types needed?

title: APIs
summary: APIs allow different software applications to communicate. They enable your program to request or send data to external services like weather data, payment systems, or databases.
sample_question: What is an API and how is it used in modern applications?

title: Databases
summary: Databases store and manage large amounts of data. SQL databases organize data in tables, while NoSQL databases store more flexible, unstructured data formats.
sample_question: What is the difference between SQL and NoSQL databases?

title: Version Control (Git)
summary: Version control systems like Git track changes in your code. They help you collaborate, revert mistakes, and maintain clean code history across multiple versions.
sample_question: Why is Git helpful in managing code in a team?
